This date corresponds to the official announcement of the rising death toll and the coordination of national response efforts.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died due to heavy rains and flooding in five Mexican states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing.
Veracruz confirmed 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro one.
43 people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to provide aid, including food and clean water.
Over 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply for about 263,000 affected users.
President Claudia Sheinbaum acknowledged that there were no early meteorological warnings indicating the magnitude of the rainfall.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains and flooding across five Mexican states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—have resulted in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The disaster was triggered by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which brought extreme rainfall, especially in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. The National Civil Protection Coordination, under Chief Laura Velazquez Alzua, coordinated national relief efforts, including deployment of military forces to deliver food and water. Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity to about 263,000 affected users. The Mexican government acknowledged that there were no early meteorological warnings indicating the severity of the rainfall, raising questions about the country's disaster preparedness and alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
